description.narrative: This project mainly contributes to results within Women's political participation. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020

With core funding, AMARA aims at promoting local good governance, democratic development, and social accountability at sub-national level. It operates in Battambang and Siem Reap province. As part of local good governance, the project “Women Action for Voice and Empowerment” aims to promote women in politics and increase their participation in decision making. The project “Support for Women Empowerment and Democratic Development”, AMARA aims to promote citizen rights for transparent local administration. Whereas the project “Promoting Citizen Engagement in Democratic Development”, the organization builds the capacity of grassroots CBOs and sub-national councilors to actively engage and increasing good governance practices. Municipal/District Councils and/or Commune Councils don’t have enough capacity to fulfil their duties, and marginalized groups especially women and youth are excluded from participating in decision making processes at sub-national level. AMARA builds their capacity and promotes mutual dialogues between duty bearers and rights holders. The projects focus on strengthening CBOs, gender equality, women in politics, and democratic governance and development. The project aims to achieve expected outcomes:  · Women’s representation and effective participation in political and social affairs has increased across sub-national levels.  · Increased women representation up to 25% in leadership position of Commune Council.  · Members of commune committee for women and children (CCWC), authorities, and local police are strengthened to prevent and respond to gender-based violence.  · Diverse citizens voice their needs and feedback to influence sub-national administration decision.  · Sub-national administrations (district/municipality & commune/sangkat) are transformed into more accountable and transparent that address more citizen issues.  The target groups include female and male commune councilors, CBOs, villagers and the elected candidate from political parties.
